bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, November 30, 1941

div1.p: Truby comments on the notebook found at the New York Academy, stating that it could be Lazear's record from the laboratory. He knows the Board went to see Finlay in early July, and that they started to raise mosquitoes at once, because he saw them in glass jars. As such, he disputes Agramonte's date for the beginning of the mosquito work. Truby believes it was Lazear, not Agramonte, who induced Reed to meet with Finlay.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, November 30, 1941
div1.p:
I am most excited and thrilled over
the news in your letter (Special Delivery) which
came at 5. P. M. yesterday- That may be
Lazear's record at the laboratory which
I referred to in my MMS- Will inclose
my original remarks in that famous first
rough draft, and have underline with
a blue pencil the important parts. Please
return those three pages for the old book-

I could not possibly give any
idea of the size of the pocket note
book. But I am sure of one thing that
the book in the N. Y. Academy could not
be the one- I can recall nothing about
the larger book except Reed did find
a record of the laboratory mosquitoes-
whether it was in a book or on
slips of paper I do not know - quite
naturally they would be kept in a book.
The new book may disclose many
things of importance- The start of mosquito
2
raising in the lab- for instance- It
may also tell when the Board went to
see Finlay and brought back larvae and
mosq. eggs- I have repeatedly told you
that they want to see Finlay early in
July and that they started to raise mosquitoes
at once- I know that this is so far
I saw the lab, glass jars with mosquitoes
in then when Durham & Myers were
there, and they saw them too- Pinto
confirms this- You continue to quote
Agramonte's statement, “Aug 1,” as the
start of that work. On this point I
also think that it was Lazear and not
Agramonte who induced Reed to see
Finlay earlysoon after the Board organized.
Agramonte had no more use for
Finlay's theory then any of the other Cuban doctors,
and I doubt if he proposed the visit-
Sternberg had told Reed to investigate
There is a record of this published somewhere, will put it in the book if I find it-
the insect theories and on Reed's visit to us at
an earlier date he discussed Finlay's
theory on our porch- Reed therefore
may have proposed the trip himself-
3
I am sure that these things will clean
up in time, but please be cautions about
quoting Agramonte too freely without qualifing
in some way- He is positively wrong
about Aug 1-

I am anxious to hear more about the new
book so dont keep me in suspense when you
get the info- Col Mahlon Ashford Md. Corps, Retired, is,
I think, still the Secretary of the NYC Academy and
probably has charge of the library. He will be glad
to corporate with you- He is one of the officers who
persistantly urged me to write of the story-

You may use my photographs in any way you
like. Later on I will send you more and
the films (originals) also.

I would be delighted to have more of the
reprints and also some of those in the Wyeth ad-
in the Journal AMA. Kean's idea is fine-

I think that the Daugherty wagon was
devised by a Col of that name but I really
dont know for sure. The I. M. Q. O. could tell you-
will return your photograph at a later date

Thanks for the data on the English losses
from the “Vomito” in the 1780- I found my
source of info. re. that in Havard's Hygiene 3d Edition
1917. P. 73.

Isn't this all exciting? I got a great
kick out of it all.
